Literature Review: Amphibians offer a unique opportunity to study the evolution of parental care, providing valuable insights into the ecological factors that have shaped diverse parenting strategies across vertebrates. This literature review explores the exceptional diversity of amphibian parental care, highlighting recent research that has uncovered key factors influencing the evolution and transitions between different forms of parenting.Amphibians exhibit a wide range of parental care behaviors, from simple egg attendance to complex forms of offspring provisioning and transport. This diversity is particularly evident across the three amphibian orders: Anura (frogs and toads), Caudata (salamanders and newts), and Gymnophiona (caecilians). Wells (2007) provides a comprehensive overview of amphibian parental care, emphasizing the variety of strategies employed by different species.One of the primary factors influencing the evolution of parental care in amphibians is the mode of fertilization. Vági et al. (2019) conducted a phylogenetic analysis of anurans and found that the transition from external to internal fertilization was strongly associated with the evolution of male parental care. This finding suggests that fertilization mode plays a crucial role in determining parental sex roles and care strategies.Terrestriality has also been identified as a key driver in the evolution of amphibian parental care. Gomez-Mestre et al. (2012) demonstrated that the transition from aquatic to terrestrial habitats in anurans was often accompanied by the evolution of more complex forms of parental care. This shift in habitat use likely imposed new selective pressures on offspring survival, favoring the evolution of protective behaviors by parents.The evolution of egg attendance, a common form of parental care in amphibians, has been extensively studied. Delia et al. (2017) investigated the factors promoting the evolution of egg attendance in glassfrogs and found that it was primarily driven by the need to protect eggs from dehydration in terrestrial environments. This research highlights the importance of environmental factors in shaping parental care strategies.Parental transport of offspring is another fascinating aspect of amphibian care. Brown et al. (2010) studied the evolution of tadpole transport in poison frogs and discovered that this behavior likely evolved as a response to predation pressure in small breeding pools. This finding underscores the role of predation as a selective force in the evolution of parental care.Nutritional provisioning, while less common in amphibians compared to other vertebrates, has evolved independently in several lineages. Kupfer et al. (2006) described a remarkable form of maternal care in caecilians, where mothers produce a nutrient-rich skin that is eaten by their offspring. This discovery highlights the potential for novel forms of parental care to evolve in response to specific ecological pressures.The evolution of parental sex roles in amphibians has also received considerable attention. Furness and Capellini (2019) conducted a comparative analysis of parental care across amphibians and found that male care was more likely to evolve in species with external fertilization, while female care was more common in species with internal fertilization. This research provides important insights into the factors influencing the evolution of sex-specific parental roles.Recent experimental approaches have shed light on the proximate mechanisms underlying parental care behaviors. For example, Schulte et al. (2011) investigated the hormonal basis of parental care in poison frogs and found that testosterone levels were negatively correlated with paternal care behaviors. Such studies are crucial for understanding the physiological underpinnings of parental care and how they may constrain or facilitate evolutionary transitions.The study of amphibian parental care also offers opportunities to investigate the costs and benefits of different care strategies. Ringler et al. (2015) examined the energetic costs of tadpole transport in poison frogs and found that males incurred significant metabolic costs during transport. This research highlights the trade-offs involved in parental care and the potential constraints on its evolution.In conclusion, the study of amphibian parental care provides valuable insights into the ecological factors that have shaped the evolution of parenting strategies across vertebrates. The diversity of care behaviors observed in amphibians, coupled with their varied life histories and habitat use, makes them an ideal group for addressing key questions about the evolution of parenting. Future research directions should focus on integrating phylogenetic, experimental, and physiological approaches to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the evolutionary dynamics of parental care in amphibians and other vertebrates.
